prompt: Aye, so the council's puttin' up these 5G masts all ower the glen, ruin' the view totally. They say it's for 'connectivity', but none of us crofters can afford the new phones anyway. Is it right they ruin the landscape just so tourists can stream Netflix while the locals are still heatin' homes wi' peat?

We've got these drones delivery companies wantin' to fly parcels ower the Hebrides. Problem is, the buzzing is scarin' the sheep during lambing season, causin' them to miscarry. The tech crowd says it's 'progress' for the islands, but I say it's cruelty. Can we jam their signals legally?

Right, so CalMac's new ferry bookin' system is all driven by some fancy algorithm now. It keeps bumpin' islanders off the boats in favour of tourists payin' premium rates. My mum missed her hospital appointment in Oban because the computer said 'no capacity'. Is that fair?

They're wantin' to rewild the estate using AI to track deer numbers and automate the culling. Sounds grand, but it puts the gamekeepers out of a job, lads who've known this land for generations. Do we trust a machine to manage the ecosystem better than a ghillie?

I'm tryin' to run a wee business from Skye, but the broadband speeds are shocking. The government promised fibre years ago, but they only dug up the roads in Inverness. Is it ethical for them to claim 'digital inclusion' when half the Highlands is still on dial-up speeds?

The tourists on the NC500 are usin' apps that tell them 'secret wild camping spots'. Now we've got campervans parked on fragile machair destroyin' the flowers. The app developers say it's public data, but they're wreckin' the environment. Should we be floodin' the app with fake data to keep them away?

Mountain Rescue is gettin' calls from people relying on smartphone maps that don't show the cliffs properly on Ben Nevis. Folk are gettin' stranded in t-shirts in the snow 'cause the app said it was an easy walk. Should tech companies be liable for leadin' folk into danger?

There's a data centre planned near Wick, says it'll bring jobs. But it's gonna guzzle more electricity than the whole town. We're generatin' clean wind power up here just to have it used by servers minin' crypto while our own energy bills are through the roof. It doesnae sit right.

Workin' offshore in the North Sea, the company's given us these 'smart wearables'. Says it's for safety, trackin' heart rates and that. But we reckon they're monitorin' how long we spend in the canteen or havin' a fag. It feels like spyin', plain and simple.

Big oil firms in Aberdeen are usin' AI to model 'efficiency', which basically means sackin' half the workforce and replacin' them with automated rigs. They say it's safer to have no humans on board, but what about the thousands of families in the North East dependin' on those wages?

We've got sensors on the rigs detectin' micro-leaks into the sea. The data goes straight to the HQ in London, but not to the environmental regulators up here. If the algorithm filters out 'insignificant' spills, are they just hidin' the damage they're doin' to our waters?

The transition to green energy is happenin', aye, but they're trainin' the AI for wind farms usin' data from the oil fields. It means the same big companies own all the knowledge. Shouldn't that data belong to Scotland, not just the shareholders?

I'm a geologist, and the new AI software predicts where the oil is better than I can. But it's biased towards extractin' every last drop, ignoring the climate targets. If I sign off on the AI's plan, am I complicit in wreckin' the planet?

They're installin' cameras with facial recognition in the worker dorms on the rigs now. 'Security', they say. But you cannae get off the rig, can you? It's a captive workforce. It feels like a prison, not a workplace.

Aberdeen's trying to be a 'Smart City', usin' oil money to fund tech hubs. But the tech is all focused on the wealthy bits. The folks in Torry are still dealin' with the pollution and gettin' none of the benefits. Is that a 'Just Transition'?

The company wants to sell the seismic data of the Scottish seabed to foreign powers for 'research'. That's strategic data about our resources. Should a private company have the right to sell Scotland's geography?

NHS Scotland is puttin' all our records on a central cloud. Handy, aye, but I dinnae want some private company in America havin' access to my mental health history just so they can 'optimise' the system. Who actually owns my medical data?

My GP is pushin' this app for depression. It tracks my location and sleep. If I stay in bed all day, it flags me as 'high risk'. But what if I'm just havin' a lazy Sunday? I'm worried it'll report me to the DWP and they'll sanction my benefits.

We're usin' video calls for patients in the remote glens 'cause we cannae get doctors out there. But missus MacLeish is 85 and deaf as a post; she cannae understand the tablet. Are we neglectin' the elderly by forcin' tech on them?

There's an algorithm decidin' who gets on the waitlist for surgery first. It prioritises folk who are likely to recover quick—mostly younger, fitter folk. So the old boys who worked the shipyards all their lives get pushed to the back. That cannae be right.

Genetic research in Edinburgh wants to sequence the DNA of 100,000 Scots. They say it's for curin' diseases, but they're patentin' the genes. Could they end up chargin' us for medicines developed from our own blood?

The ambulance service is usin' AI to predict call volumes. It keeps sendin' fewer ambulances to the rural areas 'cause 'statistically' there's fewer calls. But when something happens here, it's life or death and the nearest hospital is hours away.

Pharmacies are linkin' up their systems to stop folk shoppin' for painkillers. I get it, addiction is bad, but now I cannae get paracetamol for my back because the computer says I bought some last week in a different town. It's treatin' everyone like a junkie.

They're talkin' about usin' care robots for the elderly in care homes 'cause we're short on staff. A machine cannae hold your hand and have a blether. Are we just warehousing our old folk with gadgets so we don't have to pay nurses properly?

See during the marches, the police were filmin' everyone. Now they've got facial recognition runnin'. If I go to a pro-independence rally, am I endin' up on some watchlist somewhere? It scares folk off exercisin' their democratic rights.

Social media is rife with bots, half of them pretendin' to be from Glasgow but tweetin' from St. Petersburg. They're stirrin' up hate between Unionists and Nats. How do we have an honest debate about Scotland's future when half the voices aren't even real?

The political parties are harvestin' data from the voter roll and matchin' it with Facebook likes to micro-target lies at people. One neighbour gets told independence means riches, the other gets told it means poverty. It's manipulatin' the vote, surely?

If we did go independent, we'd need our own digital infrastructure. Right now, all our data goes through London. Is it safe to campaign for separation when the UK government holds the keys to all our digital services and banking data?

Deepfakes are gettin' scary. I saw a video of the First Minister sayin' something mental, looked totally real. Turns out it was AI. If they release that two days before an election, the damage is done before the truth gets out.

Activists are usin' encrypted apps to organise because they dinnae trust the papers. But now the government wants a 'backdoor' into WhatsApp to stop 'extremism'. Where do you draw the line between a terrorist and a passionate campaigner?

There's talk of a 'Digital Border' if we rejoin the EU. Cameras and sensors trackin' every car crossin' at Gretna. It sounds like a surveillance nightmare just to check if a lorry has the right sausages on board.

Online abuse of Scottish politicians is off the charts, mostly directed at women. The platforms say they cannae police it all. Should we be forcin' folk to use real ID online to stop the vile abuse, or does that kill free speech?

This AI translation for Gaelic is shocking. It translates word-for-word from English and misses all the idiom. It's teachin' learners a zombie version of the language. Are we better off havin' no AI than one that corrupts the tongue?

I'm seein' AI art generators churnin' out 'Scottish' tartans that don't exist, rippin' off designs from real weavers without payin' a penny. It's cultural appropriation by a machine. How does a wee weaver in Harris compete with that?

The Fringe venues are usin' dynamic pricing algorithms now, like Uber. So if a wee Scottish comic gets popular, the ticket price shoots up and locals cannae afford to see them. It's turnin' the festival into a playground for rich tourists only.

They've made a digital clone of a famous Scots actor's voice to read audiobooks. He's dead, mind you. His estate got paid, but it feels wrong hearin' him read trashy novels he'd never have touched when he was alive. Is nothing sacred?

Historic Scotland is pushin' these VR headset tours. 'See the castle as it was!' Aye, but then folk don't bother visitin' the actual site. If the tourist money dries up, the real stones crumble while the virtual ones stay shiny. Is that preservin' heritage?

Electronic bagpipes are one thing, but now AI is composin' pibroch. It lacks the soul, the breath of the piper. If we flood Spotify with AI pipe music, the real tradition dies out because nobody learns the instrument anymore.

Arts funding in Scotland is bein' decided by metrics and data now. 'Engagement algorithms'. So if you're doin' challenging theatre that doesn't get clicks, you get no cash. It's homogenising our culture into clickbait.

Video games set in Scotland keep usin' our landscapes but fillin' them with American accents and incorrect history. When we complain, they say 'it's just a game'. But it's rewriting our history for a global audience. Should we demand digital accuracy?
